title: Jaguar‚Äôs Rebrand: A Bold Leap or a Misstep in Luxury? My Hot Take.

text: We independently research, test, review, and recommend the best products‚Äîlearn more about our process. If you buy something through our links, we may earn a commission. Here‚Äôs my take on the Jaguar rebrand. JUST in case you needed another opinion. First off, we can all agree‚Äîit Stands The Flock Out. ü¶© The new Jaguar Typo 00 (Miami Pink) with Our Mascot, Pinky, Driving. Jaguar has our attention. But virality alone doesn‚Äôt make a rebrand successful. It‚Äôs just a tactic. A truly effective rebrand resonates with its audience, builds trust, and creates long-term value‚Äînot just buzz. And Jaguar‚Äôs rebrand isn‚Äôt there yet. That‚Äôs why I waited to comment until I saw the concept cars. Now that I have, my opinion is‚Ä¶ mixed. The concept cars are undeniably bold‚Äî‚Äúexuberant,‚Äù stylish, minimal, and futuristic. They align with Jaguar‚Äôs new vision and, I must say, feel very on-brand for JUST Creative. I‚Äôd drive the pink Type 00 (naturally), though that‚Äôs purely personal taste. Jaguar Typo 00 Side Profile Looking at the bigger picture, Jaguar‚Äôs rebrand aims to target ‚Äúyounger, wealthier, more urban consumers‚Äù with fewer, higher-priced cars. While I could *just* fit into this persona, I still feel the rebrand falls short of fully delivering on its promise. The high-fashionesque logo and generic typography feel ironic for a brand touting ‚ÄúCopy Nothing.‚Äù They‚Äôre forgettable, derivative, and lacks the distinctiveness Jaguar needs to make this claim successful. (Cue hot takes.) Jaguar is taking a chance, evolving, and attempting to redefine luxury and performance‚Äînot appease nostalgic critics. Will this be a roaring comeback or a quiet whimper? html:
We independently research, test, review, and recommend the best products‚Äîlearn more about our process. If you buy something through our links, we may earn a commission.

Here‚Äôs my take on the Jaguar rebrand. JUST in case you needed another opinion.

First off, we can all agree‚Äîit Stands The Flock Out. ü¶©

Jaguar has our attention.

But virality alone doesn‚Äôt make a rebrand successful. It‚Äôs just a tactic.

A truly effective rebrand resonates with its audience, builds trust, and creates long-term value‚Äînot just buzz.

And Jaguar‚Äôs rebrand isn‚Äôt there yet.

That‚Äôs why I waited to comment until I saw the concept cars. Now that I have, my opinion is‚Ä¶ mixed.

The concept cars are undeniably bold‚Äî‚Äúexuberant,‚Äù stylish, minimal, and futuristic. They align with Jaguar‚Äôs new vision and, I must say, feel very on-brand for JUST Creative.

I‚Äôd drive the pink Type 00 (naturally), though that‚Äôs purely personal taste.

Looking at the bigger picture, Jaguar‚Äôs rebrand aims to target ‚Äúyounger, wealthier, more urban consumers‚Äù with fewer, higher-priced cars. While I could *just* fit into this persona, I still feel the rebrand falls short of fully delivering on its promise.

The high-fashionesque logo and generic typography feel ironic for a brand touting ‚ÄúCopy Nothing.‚Äù They‚Äôre forgettable, derivative, and lacks the distinctiveness Jaguar needs to make this claim successful.

As for the marketing, Mark Ritson summed it up perfectly: ‚Äúoverblown, disconnected from automotive customers, and filled with bollocks.‚Äù

That said, Jaguar is breaking the playbook and challenging convention‚Äîsomething branding critics, myself included, aren‚Äôt always quick to embrace. (Cue hot takes.)

Jaguar is taking a chance, evolving, and attempting to redefine luxury and performance‚Äînot appease nostalgic critics.

Will this be a roaring comeback or a quiet whimper?

Only time will tell.

Here are a few more hot takes:

  • Anneli Hansson on Jaguar Rebrand ‚ÄúAsk the right questions‚Äù
  • Scott Galloway on Jaguar Rebrand ‚ÄúWorst brand move of 2024‚Äù
  • Forbes on Jaguar Rebrand ‚ÄúAbsolute Genius‚Äù
  • Mark Ritson on Jaguar Rebrand ‚ÄúJaguar needed to revitalize not rebrand‚Äù
